learning_outcomes.description: Explain the clinical importance of altered nutrient intake in a dental context.
Assess the impact of bone metabolism and diseases on care planning for dental treatment.
Illustrate consequences of endocrine disorders on oral health and disease.
Understand the role played by genetic, cellular, and molecular abnormalities on oral cancer and orofacial clefts.
Appreciate specific molecular mechanisms that regulate wound healing, tissue repair and tissue regeneration in dental therapies.
Describe dental tissue engineering and advances in materials and scaffolds.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment will enable the student to demonstrate the scope and depth of the learning in areas relevant to the theoretical and applied knowledge in this course (LO 1-4)

A 60 minute exam consisting of different question types including but not limited to multiple choice, short answer questions, short essays and problem-solving.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.category: Creative Production/ Exhibition, Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Performance
assessments.task_description:
A major focus of this course is for the student to develop a comprehensive understanding of the science underpinning dental practice, especially around molecular process in health and disease as well as the effect of key systemic conditions on oral health. A secondary focus is for the student to develop an appreciation of how specific molecular mechanisms that regulate wound healing co-relate to tissue regeneration in dental therapies, and understanding the rapid advances occurring in this area.

As part of this assessment, students will work in teams of 4 students:

  • Students are expected to work cohesively as a team to search, analyse and critique relevant literature with respect to systemic condition/s contributing to oral health and disease, in turn, influencing dental care planning. Students can further incorporate concepts of dental tissue engineering and how this is used to manage specific conditions.
  • The detailed review will inform the scripting and creation of an engaging 10 minute video by the student team.
  • Student teams will need to contribute as per a Couse Team Charter provided at start of semester, and this team charter will need to be submitted as part of the final submission.


The assessment will be marked to published criteria standards that will be provided via the learning management system.

All three components will need to be submitted by each team before the due date.

Students will also rate team member contributions and a peer assessment factor will be applied to the final mark.

Detailed task descriptions, marking criteria and expectations will be provided on Blackboard at start of semester.

Learning activities will be scaffolded to permit students time to create and build rapport to complete team based learning activities in class.

Please note that use of flowcharts, graphics and images should be from UQ licenced sources such as Adobe Stock and all material must be appropriately acknowledged as per the Copyright Act.

Note to student teams: You must acknowledge where you used AI in this assessment, including where you have directly quoted or paraphrased AI-generated content or used tools to summarise readings, brainstorm ideas, plan your process, or for editing/ proofreading purposes or for video content creation. You may be asked to acknowledge AI using a cover sheet, form, template or table.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
• A 90 minute exam consisting of different question types including but not limited to multiple choice, short answer questions, short essays and problem-solving covering all learning materials within this course.
  • This is a MUST PASS assessment item
  • Feedback to exams may be requested through the processes as defined by School of Dentistry student services.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Workshops

3 hour workshop every Tuesday from 1 pm.


Sub-activity: Effects of nutrition on oral health and common oral conditions (caries, periodontal disease, tooth surface loss, maternal nutrition during pregnancy, post natal care); Consequences of altered nutrient intake: excess (lifestyle disorders) & inadequate intake - effect on oral health, disease and management in clinic; Hormones, mechanism of action; Metabolic disease with effects on oral health, disease and influence on dental management; Biochemical and clinical consequences of genetic, cellular, and molecular abnormalities; Applied cell and molecular biology concepts: cells, signaling mechanisms and regulation; Materials applied in oral and dental tissue engineering; Case based collaborative learning workshops: Introduction to clinical practice and implications for care planning.

Self-paced Ultra resources

Self-paced (Self Directed Learning) 30- 60 mins a week to further explore workshop content
learning_activities.topic_description: Self-paced Ultra resources Self-paced (Self Directed Learning) 30- 60 mins a week to further explore workshop content
